It almost spit a mouthful of water against my monitor when I read today's David Brooks conclusion that Mr. Ryan had "intellectually coherent" reasons to vote against the Simpson-Bowles plan.  Which led me again to question the intellectually honesty (and perhaps emotional stability) of our Mr. Brooks.  Ryan is far from intellectually rigorous or coherent.  I suppose the bar is set so low by this crop of House members that the cataract scarred remaining eye of the one-eyed man makes him the leader of the blind, the senseless andf the heartless.  He finds himself having to backpedal vigorously over his Akin alliance; he wll soon have to answer (as best he can) a broad range of current positions that are wholy or largely at odds with positions on the same issues he held during his House tenure.  In my estimation, Sarah Palin was a better, more consistent VP candidate for the GOP.

Very compelling argument you have made here regarding the genesis and arc of one Mr. Ryan. I agree too with your observation that truth can be a powerfully effective cleanser, unless of course its opposite is skillfully managed to appear in its place. Knowing the difference between the one and the other requires a personal skill-set that goes beyond ones own fears and biases; it requires some level of rigor in thought and analysis. That implies an education or base of experiences sufficient to the task, a willingness to apply the necessary time and effort to use it, and the means to effectively register the resulting choice (i.e. vote). I fear that 50.1% of our electorate no longer possesses any of the requisites, or otherwise will be rebuffed from effectively deploying them (for the latter, see the republicans latest efforts to put sweeping voter id laws into effect).

Ryan's other eighth grade obsession is tied to Erik Erikson's 5th developmental stage, identity vs. role confusion. Ryan formed a powerful new archetype. He synthesized his natural instinct, a lack of charity toward others, by serving in positions from which he benefitted and by making his denial and indifference about the poor and his peers appear to be a form of moral justice. To him, the poor are not needy or infirm, they are evil. His votes on abortions are backed by floor speeches that see loop holes (not compassion!) in the exceptions. He tells rally audiences the medicare overpayment savings are "your" money, but his plan redistributes the same money to the wealthy and taxes his rally audiences even more. He turns moral justice upside down.

He flips economics, too. A supply sider, he clings to (and now hides!) views that have been rapaciously discredited. In the heat of the moment, he ignores the property of truth Dr. Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. cited: “Truth crushed to earth will rise again.”

He represents a campaign whose entire strategy is betting against truth’s rise, staking truth’s adaptivity can be twisted and crushed by fear. He has no views on China using economics as soft power. He never mentions manufacturing. He ignores the Euro-zone. Money is not his speciality. Deceit is, applied to money and people.

He makes it on an irony. Truth is rarely a political force. Truth is foremost an inner quality, a force he lacks, that builds a fabric of trust.

As much as I-and my kids-have admired Lance, you cannot watch Tyler Hamilton's 60 Minutes interview and not come away knowing of Armstrong's guilt. It is that powerful. I love Cycling, it's too bad. Watch the interview.
you can keep admiring him, that's only because you don't know his true character.

Implicit in 'dedicated to his sport' is the idea that you follow the rules of that sport. I was taught and I believe that competing in sport, or life for that matter, isn't just about winning it's also about adhering to the rules because it's not just the result that’s important but the process that attempts to make things fair. Doped (if he did use illicit substances to enhance performance) Mr. Armstrong would have demeaned not only himself but all of those who competed against him and attempted to receive an honor that was not his due.

Thank you Sister Marie Jacque for drilling into my being the simple maxim: "Right is right if no one is right and wrong is wrong if everyone's wrong." At least I have some sure guideline for measuring honesty and truth and honor.

This whole case against Lance Armstrong has always had a bad smell to me, the zealotry with which he has been pursued seems unusually intense.

Especially since 9-11, the whole tone of our country seems to me to have shifted, where the American ideal was "innocent under proven guilty" and now seems to be the reverse in many cases. We are often a punitive country and to paraphrase a saying I heard some time ago, American loves its heroes but seems to love to see them fall even more.

One thing which Mr. Armstrong did not fake was his recovery from cancer, and the grueling miles he rode consistently year after year, 'doped' or not, show a tremendous dedication to his sport. I am unconvinced of his guilt, I do admire his tenaciousness and perseverance.

Gladbach's transfer activity seemed to be based on the idea that they'd be in the CL group stages but players like Xhaka and de Jong will serve them well in the BL. And ultimately a deep Europa League run may be what the club needs if they want to cement themselves as a fixture in Europe. Repeating in the top four this year might be tough -- I have some combination of Bayern, BVB, Leverkusen and Wolfsburg -- but Europa League qualification is an attainable goal and would bring in enough cash and profile to help Gladbach further establish itself themselves as a fixture in the upper tier of the always chaotic Bundesliga. Considering Gladbach seemed a certainty for relegation two seasons ago, it's a credit to Favre. I only wish Hertha hadn't been so short-sighted and let him go. If Hertha management had been patient, Die Alte Dame might have been playing in Europe instead of traveling Sandhausen and Regensburg.
